title: India vs Bangladesh, one-off Test, Day 3: Live Cricket Scores : Cricket, News - India Today
text:
Virat Kohli the batsman changed completely after 2014 Australia Tour: Sourav Ganguly to India Today 
India captain Virat Kohli's record-breaking spree continued on Friday as he smashed his fourth double hundred in the one-off Test against Bangladesh in Hyderabad. Kohli scored 204 from 246 balls to help his team declare at 687/6 in the first innings on Day 2 after electing to bat first at the Rajiv Gandhi International stadium. 
9.30 IST: The players are out in the middle. Tamim Iqbal and Mominul Haque will continue with the bat for Bangladesh. Bhuvneshwar Kumar will start the proceedings with the ball for India. 
9.25 IST: The second day's play only managed to bring 4 wickets, that just shows how good the pitch is for batting. Will the pitch aid spin today or will it be another batting friendly day of cricket? 
9.15 IST: Pitch Report - Sunil Gavaskar said the cracks were getting wider which should help the Indian spinners. He added that as the day will progress the cracks will keep widening up. 
9.10 IST: The visitors did not lose a single wicket till the 11th over but Umesh Yadav drew first blood via a tremendous review by the Indian skipper. They will be wanting to bat as long as possible to make the game even. The home side on the other hand will want to keep on picking wickets at regular intervals to keep mounting pressure on the opposition. Hope it is an exciting day of cricket. Join us in a while as the start isn't far. 
9.00 IST: The hosts sit on top of the game after batting extremely well. With the exception of KL Rahul, every other Indian batsmen was amongst the runs. The massive total on the board means that the Bangladeshi players were under pressure heading into the fag end of the day. 
Brief Day 2 Report: Virat Kohli struck his fourth double century as India declared on 687/6 and demoralised Bangladesh further by taking a wicket on a record-filled day two of their one-off Test. 
Bangladesh reached 41/1 in 14 overs, losing Soumya Sarkar to an edge on 15 two overs before stumps at Rajiv Ghandi International Stadium. 
Bangladesh trail by 646 runs, with Tamim Iqbal on 24, and Mominul Haque on 1. 
Kohli, resuming from 111 overnight, scored 204 from 246 deliveries, and hit 24 fours. He became the first batsman in cricket history to post double hundreds in four consecutive Test series.
